member.name: T:WizardWrx.DLLConfigurationManager.ExceptionLogger
member.summary:
This Singleton class exposes methods for formatting data from instances of the System.Exception class, and commonly used derived classes, and displaying the formatted data on a console (strictly speaking, on STDOUT, which can be redirected to a file), and recording them in a Windows event log.
Unlike most of the classes defined in this library, this class may be inherited.
All methods of this class are thread-safe. See Remarks.
member.remarks:
This class was developed to report exceptions in a multi threaded console application. Its methods were designed to report messages in a manner that is thread-safe, yet keeps each message intact.
Both objectives are achieved fairly easily.
1) All methods use only local variables. The only class level static data is a handful of constants, which are, by definition, read only, and the private SyncRoot object used to synchronize access to the object and its properties. This satisfies the first condition of thread safety, because all methods have exclusive access to all of their data.
2) Each message is built up, line by line, by appending to an instance of a StringBuilder class, using its AppendFormat method, which behaves like the static Format method of the System.String class. Although the AppendFormat method is an instance method, since the associated instance is local, thread safety remains intact. See Reference 1.
2) A single call to TextWriter.Synchronized ( Console.Out ).WriteLine or TextWriter.Synchronized ( Console.Error ).WriteLine writes the message, all at once, onto the console, preserving its integrity. Since the only event that uses a shared resource is called once only, and that call is synchronized, the message display is intact.
Since each method uses the shared resource, access to the console Standard Error (STDERR) stream, once only, and does so in a synchronized (thread-safe) way, the entire method is thread-safe.
As a reminder to include WizardWrx.DLLServices2.dll in your projects, I left this class in the WizardWrx.DLLServices2 namespace. Only symbolic constants got promoted to the root namespace.

member.name: T:WizardWrx.DLLConfigurationManager.ExceptionLogger.OutputOptions
member.summary: Use these flags to control the output. There is no flag for the Message property, which always becomes part of the message.
member.remarks:
DiscardNewlines and NBSpaceForNewlines arose to resolve an issue that came to light when a desire arose to reconstruct an exception report from the message posted into a Microsoft Excel workbook that was populated from the output of a run of PsLogList.exe. To cause it to keep each message on a single logical line, so that it would import into a single worksheet row, PsLogList.exe is invoked with its -s switch, causing PsLogList to print (output) Event Log records one-per-line, with comma delimited fields.
To preserve the newlines in the event log file and have some indication of their original positions when PsLogList strips them, set the NBSpaceForNewlines flag to TRUE. This causes each embedded newline to be preceded in the output by a NOLBREAKING_SPACE (ASCII character code 160, A0h, Unicode code point U+0A0) character.
To substitute a NOLBREAKING_SPACE for each newline, set this flag AND DiscardNewlines to TRUE.

member.name: F:WizardWrx.DLLConfigurationManager.ExceptionLogger.OutputOptions.NoFlags
member.summary: Use this member to evaluate whether all flags are OFF.

member.name: F:WizardWrx.DLLConfigurationManager.ExceptionLogger.OutputOptions.Method
member.summary:
Show Method Name if TRUE.
If the EventLog flag is also set, the method name is always written there.

member.name: F:WizardWrx.DLLConfigurationManager.ExceptionLogger.OutputOptions.Source
member.summary:
Show Source (Assembly) Name if TRUE.
If the EventLog flag is also set, the originating assembly name is always written there.

member.name: F:WizardWrx.DLLConfigurationManager.ExceptionLogger.OutputOptions.Stack
member.summary:
Show Stack Trace if TRUE.
If the EventLog flag is also set, the stack trace is always written there.

member.name: F:WizardWrx.DLLConfigurationManager.ExceptionLogger.OutputOptions.EventLog
member.summary:
Post to associated event log if TRUE.
The value of the event source associated with the current ExceptionLogger instance determines which event log gets the message.
WARNING: Unless your event source string is already registered, the application MUST run, one time only, with full administrator privileges AND use the event source to write a message into the Windows event log in order for it to be registered with Windows, which maps it to an event log. Alternatively, you may register the event source by any number of other means, such as by way of an installation script.
Once the event source string is registered, the application can use it to post messages to the event log in any Windows security context.

member.name: F:WizardWrx.DLLConfigurationManager.ExceptionLogger.OutputOptions.StandardOutput
member.summary:
Write message on STDOUT if TRUE and if the application has a working console.
The setting of this flag also governs the behavior of the ScrollUp method.
CAUTION: Although it is technically legal to set both StandardOutput and StandardError to TRUE, this can have the unwanted consequence of generating TWO copies of the message, unless STDOUT and/or STDERR is directed to a file or if both are redirected to the SAME file.

member.name: F:WizardWrx.DLLConfigurationManager.ExceptionLogger.OutputOptions.StandardError
member.summary:
Write message on STDERR if TRUE and if the application has a working console.
The setting of this flag also governs the behavior of the ScrollUp method.
CAUTION: Although it is technically legal to set both StandardOutput and StandardError to TRUE, this can have the unwanted consequence of generating TWO copies of the message, unless STDOUT and/or STDERR is directed to a file or if both are redirected to the SAME file.

member.name: F:WizardWrx.DLLConfigurationManager.ExceptionLogger.OutputOptions.DiscardNewlines
member.summary:
Discard newlines entirely, unless NBSpaceForNewlines is also true, in which case each newline is retained, preceded by a NOLBREAKING_SPACE (ASCII character code 160, A0h, U+0A0) character.
Please see the Remarks on the enumeration for important details.

member.name: F:WizardWrx.DLLConfigurationManager.ExceptionLogger.OutputOptions.NBSpaceForNewlines
member.summary:
Precede each newline with a NOLBREAKING_SPACE (ASCII character code 160, A0h, Unicode code point U+0A0) character, unless DiscardNewlines is also true, in which case a NOLBREAKING_SPACE precedes the newline, which is preserved.
Please see the Remarks on the enumeration for important details.

member.name: F:WizardWrx.DLLConfigurationManager.ExceptionLogger.OutputOptions.ReplaceNewlines
member.summary: Deploy this flag combination to substitute a NOLBREAKING_SPACE (ASCII character code 160, A0h, Unicode code point U+0A0) for every platform-dependent newline. On a Windows platform, the outcome is a slightly shorter message string, since each space replaces two characters. In all cases, the NOLBREAKING_SPACE guarantees that each event record occupies one line when output as text, while providing a means of restoring the newlines by reversing the replacement.

member.name: F:WizardWrx.DLLConfigurationManager.ExceptionLogger.OutputOptions.ActiveProperties
member.summary: Use this bit mask to include all auxiliary properties of the Exception (StackTrace, TargetSite, Source, DiscardNewlines, and NBSpaceForNewlines) in the report, or to strip them form a set of flags.

member.name: F:WizardWrx.DLLConfigurationManager.ExceptionLogger.OutputOptions.ActivePropsToEventLog
member.summary: Use this bit mask to include all auxiliary properties of the Exception (StackTrace, TargetSite, and Source) in the report, and to send the report to a Windows event log.

member.name: F:WizardWrx.DLLConfigurationManager.ExceptionLogger.OutputOptions.ActivePropsToStdErr
member.summary: Use this bit mask to include all auxiliary properties of the Exception (StackTrace, TargetSite, and Source) in the report, and to send the report to the standard error stream.

member.name: F:WizardWrx.DLLConfigurationManager.ExceptionLogger.OutputOptions.ActivePropsToStdOut
member.summary: Use this bit mask to include all auxiliary properties of the Exception (StackTrace, TargetSite, and Source) in the report, and to send the report to the standard output stream.

member.name: F:WizardWrx.DLLConfigurationManager.ExceptionLogger.OutputOptions.ActivePropsEverywhere
member.summary: Use this bit mask to include all auxiliary properties of the Exception (StackTrace, TargetSite, and Source) in the report, and to send the report to a Windows event log and both the standard output and standard error streams. This is useful when you know that the standard output is redirected, and you want to preserve the report in the output file, in addition to having a copy displayed on the console.

member.name: F:WizardWrx.DLLConfigurationManager.ExceptionLogger.OutputOptions.AllProperties
member.summary: Use this flag to include all auxiliary properties of the Exception (StackTrace, TargetSite, Source, DiscardNewlines, and NBSpaceForNewlines) in the report, or to strip them form a set of flags.

member.name: F:WizardWrx.DLLConfigurationManager.ExceptionLogger.OutputOptions.AllDestiations
member.summary: Use this flag to include all destinations for output, or as a mask to strip them from a set of flags.

member.name: F:WizardWrx.DLLConfigurationManager.ExceptionLogger.OutputOptions.AllFlags
member.summary: This flag turns on everything, and is of no practical use, but is defined for reference, to document that every bit in the byte is accounted for. Now that all bits have assignments, this flag and AllProperties resolve to the same value.

member.name: T:WizardWrx.DLLConfigurationManager.ExceptionLogger.ErrorExitOptions
member.summary: Use with the static GetSpecifiedReservedErrorMessage method or with the overloaded instance GetReservedErrorMessage method that allows callers to override the behavior dictated by its properties.
member.remarks: The correspondence between the naming and numbering of the members of this enumeration is by design, since the two work hand in hand internally, and the consistency should simplify writing calls to the GetReservedErrorMessage methods.

member.name: F:WizardWrx.DLLConfigurationManager.ExceptionLogger.ErrorExitOptions.Succeeded
member.summary: Execution succeeded; return the ERROR_SUCCESS placeholder for the table of error messages.

member.name: F:WizardWrx.DLLConfigurationManager.ExceptionLogger.ErrorExitOptions.RecordedInEventLog
member.summary: Details of the run-time exception were reported in a Windows Event Log.

member.name: F:WizardWrx.DLLConfigurationManager.ExceptionLogger.ErrorExitOptions.RecordedInStandardOutput
member.summary: Details of the run-time exception were listed on STDOUT if the application has a working console.

member.name: F:WizardWrx.DLLConfigurationManager.ExceptionLogger.ErrorExitOptions.RecordedInStandardError
member.summary: Details of the run-time exception were listed on STDERR if the application has a working console.

member.name: T:WizardWrx.DLLConfigurationManager.ExceptionLogger.ScrollUpResult
member.summary: As a convenience, the ScrollUp method reports the result through a bit-mapped enumeration.

member.name: F:WizardWrx.DLLConfigurationManager.ExceptionLogger.ScrollUpResult.NoAction
member.summary: Nothing happened, most likely because the calling process runs in the Windows (graphical) User Interface subsystem, which is unsupported, though not treated as an outright failure.

member.name: F:WizardWrx.DLLConfigurationManager.ExceptionLogger.ScrollUpResult.StandardError
member.summary: The standard error console stream was scrolled up one line.

member.name: F:WizardWrx.DLLConfigurationManager.ExceptionLogger.ScrollUpResult.StandardOutput
member.summary: The standard output console stream was scrolled up one line.

member.name: F:WizardWrx.DLLConfigurationManager.ExceptionLogger.ScrollUpResult.Both
member.summary: Both console streams were scrolled up one line, which happens only when the standard output stream is redirected AND messages are being reported on both streams.

member.name: F:WizardWrx.DLLConfigurationManager.ExceptionLogger.WIZARDWRX_EVENT_SOURCE_ID
member.summary: This string defines a default event source ID, WizardWrx, which I register on behalf of my own applications.

member.name: P:WizardWrx.DLLConfigurationManager.ExceptionLogger.AppEventSourceID
member.summary:
Along with the EventLoggingState property, this property governs recording of events in the Windows Application Event Log or in a custom event log of your choice.
The value of this property is the event source ID string to use. To simplify applications, this property has a default value, defined by WIZARDWRX_EVENT_SOURCE_ID.
IMPORTANT: Each event source ID string is machine specific, and each maps to one, and only one, event log, which is designated when the source is registered, as it must be before its first use.

member.name: P:WizardWrx.DLLConfigurationManager.ExceptionLogger.ApplicationSubsystem
member.summary: The value of this property is the actual subsystem ID reported by a fully managed function that yields the same result as the usual native (unmanaged) method.
member.remarks: This property uses GetExeSubsystem in lieu of GetProcessSubsystem to circumvent an anomaly in the Visual Studio debugging engine, which causes that function to return 2 (Windows GUI subsystem) when you use the Visual Studio Hosting Process, which runs in the Windows subsystem. The cause of this behavior is that the Visual Studio Hosting Process trades places with the process under study, becoming the first executable file loaded into the active process.

member.name: P:WizardWrx.DLLConfigurationManager.ExceptionLogger.ErrorMessageColors
member.summary:
Set this property to cause error messages to be displayed in a distinctive pair of foreground and background colors.
Unless the AppSubsystem property is Console or CUI, this property is meaningless.
Unlike other properties, ErrorMessageColors must be set directly, and it may be changed at any time.
member.remarks: A hidden MessageInColor is maintained in tandem with this property, for use with STDERR. In this way, messages written to either STDOUT or STDERR use the same color scheme.

member.name: P:WizardWrx.DLLConfigurationManager.ExceptionLogger.OptionFlags
member.summary: Gets or sets the new OutputOptions enumeration, which supersedes the obsolete individual flags.

member.name: P:WizardWrx.DLLConfigurationManager.ExceptionLogger.StdErrIsRedirected
member.summary:
Return TRUE if the Standard Error console stream was redirected by the shell. Otherwise, the return value is FALSE.
This flag is meaningless unless the ApplicationSubsystem property value is equal to ProcessSubsystem.Console, indicating that the calling process is running in the Windows Character Mode (CUI) subsystem.

member.name: P:WizardWrx.DLLConfigurationManager.ExceptionLogger.StdOutIsRedirected
member.summary:
Return TRUE if the Standard Output console stream was redirected by the shell. Otherwise, the return value is FALSE.
This flag is meaningless unless the ApplicationSubsystem property value is equal to ProcessSubsystem.Console, indicating that the calling process is running in the Windows Character Mode (CUI) subsystem.

member.name: M:WizardWrx.DLLConfigurationManager.ExceptionLogger.GetTheSingleInstance
member.summary: Call this static method from anywhere to get a reference to the ExceptionLogger singleton.
member.returns: The return value is a reference to the singleton, which is created the first time the method is called. Subsequent calls return a reference to the singleton.
member.remarks:
All overloads call this method, caching the returned reference in a local variable, before they override one or more of its default property values. When all overrides have been processed, the cached reference is returned through the overload that took the call.
This roundabout procedure is necessary because the properties cannot be set until the object has been created. The most straightforward way to do this is to call the default method, which performs a task usually performed by a default constructor in this implementation of the singleton design pattern.

member.name: M:WizardWrx.DLLConfigurationManager.ExceptionLogger.GetTheSingleInstance(WizardWrx.DLLConfigurationManager.ExceptionLogger.OutputOptions)
member.summary: Call this static method from anywhere to get a reference to the ExceptionLogger singleton and set its OptionFlags property.
member.param: The OutputOptions enumeration is organized for use as a bit mask. Set its flags as desired to control the format and content of output generated by the ReportException methods.
member.returns: The return value is a reference to the singleton, which is created the first time the method is called. Subsequent calls return a reference to the singleton.

member.name: M:WizardWrx.DLLConfigurationManager.ExceptionLogger.GetTheSingleInstance(WizardWrx.AssemblyUtils.PESubsystemInfo.PESubsystemID,WizardWrx.DLLConfigurationManager.ExceptionLogger.OutputOptions,System.String)
member.summary: Call this static method from anywhere to get a reference to the ExceptionLogger singleton and set its ProcessSubsystem, OptionFlags, and AppEventSourceID properties.
member.param: Use this member of the ProcessSubsystem enumeration to modify the default behavior of the exception logging methods, by enabling console output if the calling application has one.
The OutputOptions enumeration is organized for use as a bit mask. Set its flags as desired to control the format and content of output generated by the ReportException methods.
Use this string to override the default event source ID, which is WIZARDWRX_EVENT_SOURCE_ID.
member.returns: The return value is a reference to the singleton, which is created the first time the method is called. Subsequent calls return a reference to the singleton.
member.remarks: This method looks entirely forward, which means that it doesn't bother with the obsolete properties.

member.name: M:WizardWrx.DLLConfigurationManager.ExceptionLogger.GetTheSingleInstance(WizardWrx.DLLConfigurationManager.ExceptionLogger.OutputOptions,System.String)
member.summary: Call this static method from anywhere to get a reference to the ExceptionLogger singleton and set its ProcessSubsystem, OptionFlags, and AppEventSourceID properties.
member.param: The OutputOptions enumeration is organized for use as a bit mask. Set its flags as desired to control the format and content of output generated by the ReportException methods.
Use this string to override the default event source ID, which is WIZARDWRX_EVENT_SOURCE_ID.
member.returns: The return value is a reference to the singleton, which is created the first time the method is called. Subsequent calls return a reference to the singleton.
member.remarks: This method looks entirely forward, which means that it doesn't bother with the obsolete properties.

member.name: M:WizardWrx.DLLConfigurationManager.ExceptionLogger.GetTheSingleInstance(WizardWrx.AssemblyUtils.PESubsystemInfo.PESubsystemID)
member.summary: Call this static method from anywhere to get a reference to the ExceptionLogger singleton and set its AppSubsystem property.
member.param: Use this member of the ProcessSubsystem enumeration to modify the default behavior of the exception logging methods, by enabling console output if the calling application has one.
member.returns: The return value is a reference to the singleton, which is created the first time the method is called. Subsequent calls return a reference to the singleton.

member.name: M:WizardWrx.DLLConfigurationManager.ExceptionLogger.RestoreDefaultColors(System.Boolean)
member.summary: Restore the default exception message colors.
member.param: To have the colors saved by the last call to SaveCurrentColors discarded, set this argument to TRUE. Otherwise, the saved colors are preserved.
member.returns: The return value is the reinstated default exception message colors, which may be NULL if the color scheme is invalid (both colors set to the same value) or missing (no color scheme is configured).

member.name: M:WizardWrx.DLLConfigurationManager.ExceptionLogger.GetReservedErrorMessage
member.summary: Return a message suitable for display on a console to accompany a status code of ERROR_SUCCESS (zero) or ERROR_RUNTIME (one), both defined in the MagicNumbers class of standard constant definitions.
member.returns: Since its operation is self contained, this method should always succeed in returning an appropriate message.

member.name: M:WizardWrx.DLLConfigurationManager.ExceptionLogger.GetReservedErrorMessage(WizardWrx.DLLConfigurationManager.ExceptionLogger.ErrorExitOptions)
member.summary: Return a message suitable for display on a console to accompany a status code of ERROR_SUCCESS (zero) or ERROR_RUNTIME (one), both defined in the MagicNumbers class of standard constant definitions.
member.param:
A member of the ErrorExitOptions specifies the desired action. This value overrides the corresponding bits in the OptionFlags bit mask.
If an invalid value is specified, the returned string is an error message that starts with "An internal error has occurred." If this happens, it should be treated as a coding error.
member.returns: If the function succeeds, the returned message is ready to use; appropriate substitutions have already been made. Otherwise, the return value is the error message described in the documentation of argument penmErrorExitOptions.

member.name: M:WizardWrx.DLLConfigurationManager.ExceptionLogger.OutputOptionsDisplay(System.String)
member.summary: Return a labeled string representation of the current OptionFlags, along with decimal and hexadecimal representations of the bit mask.
member.param: Specify a label to be inserted into the message. This may be the empty string, or even a null reference, to omit the label.
member.returns: The returned string is ready to display via Console.WriteLine or MessageBox.Show.

member.name: M:WizardWrx.DLLConfigurationManager.ExceptionLogger.OutputOptionTurnOff(WizardWrx.DLLConfigurationManager.ExceptionLogger.OutputOptions)
member.summary: Turn the specified bit in the OutputOptions bit mask OFF.
member.param: Specify the member of the OutputOptions enumerated type to turn OFF.
member.returns: The return value is the updated OutputOptions enumerated type, which is organized as a bit mask.

member.name: M:WizardWrx.DLLConfigurationManager.ExceptionLogger.OutputOptionTurnOn(WizardWrx.DLLConfigurationManager.ExceptionLogger.OutputOptions)
member.summary: Turn the specified bit in the OutputOptions bit mask ON.
member.param: Specify the member of the OutputOptions enumerated type to turn ON.
member.returns: The return value is the updated OutputOptions enumerated type, which is organized as a bit mask.

member.name: M:WizardWrx.DLLConfigurationManager.ExceptionLogger.RestoreDefaultOptions
member.summary: Restore the state of the OutputOptions flags to their initial (default) values.
member.returns: The return value is the reinstated property value.
member.remarks: This routine calls the same static SetDefaultOptions method used by the static initializer, so that the defaults can be changed by visiting just one routine.

member.name: M:WizardWrx.DLLConfigurationManager.ExceptionLogger.RestoreSavedOptions
member.summary: Restore the state of the OutputOptions flags from the copy saved by the last SaveCurrentOptions method call.
member.returns: This method returns the options that were just restored, so that callers can sanity check them against the expected settings.
member.remarks: CAUTION: Unless this method is preceded by a call to SaveCurrentOptions, this call clears all flags, not just back to their initial state, but truly clear - all flags OFF.

member.name: M:WizardWrx.DLLConfigurationManager.ExceptionLogger.RestoreSavedColors
member.summary: Restore the ErrorMessageColors from the copy saved by the last SaveCurrentColors method call.
member.returns: This method returns the restored message colors, so that callers may sanity check them against the expected values.
member.remarks: CAUTION: Unless this method is preceded by a call to SaveCurrentColors, this call completely disables color error messages, unless the static initializer set default colors from a configuration file.

member.name: M:WizardWrx.DLLConfigurationManager.ExceptionLogger.SaveCurrentColors
member.summary: Save a copy of the current colors defined by the ErrorMessageColors property into a private area reserved for the purpose.
member.returns: The current settings (the settings just saved) are returned.

member.name: M:WizardWrx.DLLConfigurationManager.ExceptionLogger.SaveCurrentOptions
member.summary: Save a copy of the current state of the OutputOptions flags into a private area reserved for the purpose.
member.returns: The current settings (the settings just saved) are returned.

member.name: M:WizardWrx.DLLConfigurationManager.ExceptionLogger.GetSpecifiedReservedErrorMessage(WizardWrx.DLLConfigurationManager.ExceptionLogger.ErrorExitOptions)
member.summary:
Return a message suitable for display on a console to accompany a status code of ERROR_SUCCESS (zero) or ERROR_RUNTIME (one), both defined in the MagicNumbers class of standard constant definitions.
Call this method with penmErrorExitOptions equal to Succeeded to get the ERROR_SUCCESS placeholder string for your error message table.
member.param:
A member of the ErrorExitOptions specifies the desired action. Since this is a static method, and doesn't have access to the instance properties, this value substitutes for the corresponding bits in the OptionFlags bit mask.
If an invalid value is specified, the returned string is an error message that starts with "An internal error has occurred." If this happens, it should be treated as a coding error.
member.returns: If the function succeeds, the returned message is ready to use; appropriate substitutions have already been made. Otherwise, the return value is the error message described in the documentation of argument penmErrorExitOptions.

member.name: M:WizardWrx.DLLConfigurationManager.ExceptionLogger.TimeStampedTraceWrite(System.String)
member.summary: Append a message to a standard ISO-8601 time stamp.
member.param: Specify the message to record.
member.remarks: Though written ostensibly for internal use, I marked this method as public because it will quickly find employment outside this library.

member.name: M:WizardWrx.DLLConfigurationManager.ExceptionLogger.ReportException(System.Exception)
member.summary: Format and report the properties of a generic Exception on a console in a thread-safe manner.
member.param: The instance of the base Exception class to process. See Remarks.
member.returns:
The return value is the string that was written onto the standard error or standard output stream (or both, depending on the flags).
NOTE: The returned string is terminated by a single newline. Since it is appended to the stream by a Console.Write, the carriage is returned to the next line, but no additional line feeds follow. Hence, if you want your error message to be followed by a blank line, you must follow this call with an empty Console.WriteLine or,
member.remarks:
This can be ANY exception type, although the intent is to limit its use to reporting exceptions thrown by the base class, System.Exception.
Other overloads exist for reporting exceptions thrown by types derived from System.Exception.
The TargetSite property, exposed by descendants of System.Exception, is the name of the method in which the exception was thrown.

member.name: M:WizardWrx.DLLConfigurationManager.ExceptionLogger.ReportException(System.ArgumentException)
member.summary: Format and report the properties of an ArgumentException exception on a console in a thread-safe manner.
member.param: The instance of the ArgumentException exception to process. See Remarks.
member.returns:
The return value is the string that was written onto the standard error or standard output stream (or both, depending on the flags).
NOTE: The returned string is terminated by a single newline. Since it is appended to the stream by a Console.Write, the carriage is returned to the next line, but no additional line feeds follow. Hence, if you want your error message to be followed by a blank line, you must follow this call with an empty Console.WriteLine or,
member.remarks:
Although this method can process objects of ANY class which derives from ArgumentException, other methods of this class specialize in processing objects of the commonly used ArgumentOutOfRangeException and ArgumentNullException derived classes.
The TargetSite property, exposed by descendants of System.Exception, is the name of the method in which the exception was thrown.

member.name: M:WizardWrx.DLLConfigurationManager.ExceptionLogger.ReportException(System.ArgumentOutOfRangeException)
member.summary: Format and report the properties of an ArgumentOutOfRangeException exception on a console in a thread-safe manner.
member.param: The instance of the ArgumentOutOfRangeException class to process.
member.returns:
The return value is the string that was written onto the standard error or standard output stream (or both, depending on the flags).
NOTE: The returned string is terminated by a single newline. Since it is appended to the stream by a Console.Write, the carriage is returned to the next line, but no additional line feeds follow. Hence, if you want your error message to be followed by a blank line, you must follow this call with an empty Console.WriteLine or,
member.remarks: The TargetSite property, exposed by descendants of System.Exception, is the name of the method in which the exception was thrown.

member.name: M:WizardWrx.DLLConfigurationManager.ExceptionLogger.ReportException(System.ArgumentNullException)
member.summary: Format and report the properties of an ArgumentNullException exception on a console in a thread-safe manner. See Remarks.
member.param: The instance of an ArgumentNullException exception to process.
member.returns:
The return value is the string that was written onto the standard error or standard output stream (or both, depending on the flags).
NOTE: The returned string is terminated by a single newline. Since it is appended to the stream by a Console.Write, the carriage is returned to the next line, but no additional line feeds follow. Hence, if you want your error message to be followed by a blank line, you must follow this call with an empty Console.WriteLine or,
member.remarks: The TargetSite property, exposed by descendants of System.Exception, is the name of the method in which the exception was thrown.

member.name: M:WizardWrx.DLLConfigurationManager.ExceptionLogger.ReportException(System.ObjectDisposedException)
member.summary: Format and report the properties of an ObjectDisposedException exception on a console in a thread-safe manner. See Remarks.
member.param: The instance of the ObjectDisposedException Exception class to process.
member.returns:
The return value is the string that was written onto the standard error or standard output stream (or both, depending on the flags).
NOTE: The returned string is terminated by a single newline. Since it is appended to the stream by a Console.Write, the carriage is returned to the next line, but no additional line feeds follow. Hence, if you want your error message to be followed by a blank line, you must follow this call with an empty Console.WriteLine or,
member.remarks:
Any process that throws an ObjectDisposedException exception is in serious trouble, and deserves to crash, and be investigated, because this type of exception is almost invariably caused by a programming logic error.
The TargetSite property, exposed by descendants of System.Exception, is the name of the method in which the exception was thrown.

member.name: M:WizardWrx.DLLConfigurationManager.ExceptionLogger.ReportException(System.IO.IOException,System.IO.FileInfo)
member.summary: Format and report the properties of an IOException exception on a console in a thread-safe manner.
member.param: The instance of the IOException class to process. See Remarks.
The FileInfo object makes available much more than the file name, allowing for the possibility of an override to deliver more detailed information about the file being processed.
member.returns:
The return value is the string that was written onto the standard error or standard output stream (or both, depending on the flags).
NOTE: The returned string is terminated by a single newline. Since it is appended to the stream by a Console.Write, the carriage is returned to the next line, but no additional line feeds follow. Hence, if you want your error message to be followed by a blank line, you must follow this call with an empty Console.WriteLine or,
member.remarks:
This routine processes ANY exception of the IOException class and its derivatives. Methods for parsing published derived classes are somewhere on my ToDo list.
The TargetSite property, exposed by descendants of System.Exception, is the name of the method in which the exception was thrown.

member.name: M:WizardWrx.DLLConfigurationManager.ExceptionLogger.ReportException(System.FormatException,System.String)
member.summary: Format and report the properties of an FormatException exception on a console in a thread-safe manner.
member.param: The instance of the FormatException class to process.
This should be the format string which caused the exception. There should be a way to feed this to the exception, or recover it, but I have yet to find it.
member.returns:
The return value is the string that was written onto the standard error or standard output stream (or both, depending on the flags).
NOTE: The returned string is terminated by a single newline. Since it is appended to the stream by a Console.Write, the carriage is returned to the next line, but no additional line feeds follow. Hence, if you want your error message to be followed by a blank line, you must follow this call with an empty Console.WriteLine or,
member.remarks: The TargetSite property, exposed by descendants of System.Exception, is the name of the method in which the exception was thrown.

member.name: P:WizardWrx.DLLConfigurationManager.ExceptionLogger.s_strSettingsOmittedFromConfigFile
member.summary: Once an instance has spring into being, this static property returns the configuration values that are missing a setting in the configuration file.

member.name: M:WizardWrx.DLLConfigurationManager.ExceptionLogger.GetStandardHandleStates(WizardWrx.DLLConfigurationManager.StateManager)
member.summary: The StateManager calls this method once, immediately after both it and the ExceptionLogger exist.
member.param: To simplify matters a bit, the state manager passes a reference to itself.

member.name: M:WizardWrx.DLLConfigurationManager.ExceptionLogger.OptionIsOn(WizardWrx.DLLConfigurationManager.ExceptionLogger.OutputOptions)
member.summary: Test whether an OutputOptions is ON or OFF.
member.param: Specify the OutputOptions enumeration member to test.
member.returns: Return TRUE if the specified option is ON; otherwise, return FALSE.

member.name: M:WizardWrx.DLLConfigurationManager.ExceptionLogger.ReportAsDirected(System.String,System.String)
member.summary: Report as indicated by the flags stored in the _enmOutputOptions bit mask.
member.param: The message string to return to the caller.
To correctly report inner exceptions, the messages for the user and the event log must be segregated and built concurrently.
member.returns: The message to report.
member.remarks:
This is the only private instance method. Making it static would require four additional arguments into it. I'd rather save those 128 bytes of stack frame for when I really need it.
The same message is recorded on the console, if so indicated, and in the application event log, EXCEPT that the copy that goes into the event log ALWAYS gets a stack trace attached for the exception and each inner exception, if any. Finally, the text is returned, so that the caller can use it, for example, in a message box.

member.name: M:WizardWrx.DLLConfigurationManager.ExceptionLogger.ScrollUp
member.summary: Scroll up one line upon request, unless the system already generated a blank line by passing the message to a WriteLine method, which appends a second newline following the one that's already there, since every message ends with a newline.
member.returns: The return value is a member of the ScrollUpResult bit mapped enumeration, which indicates which console stream(s) got scrolled. A message that goes out by way of a WriteLine method doesn't get one, since it's already scrolled up.

member.name: M:WizardWrx.DLLConfigurationManager.ExceptionLogger.SetMessageColors
member.summary: This method attends to default message colors, setting or reinstating them as needed.

member.name: M:WizardWrx.DLLConfigurationManager.ExceptionLogger.AddCommonElementsReportAndReturn(System.Exception,System.Text.StringBuilder,System.Text.StringBuilder)
member.summary: The last two blocks of every ReportException method are identical, and are extracted to reduce the code size.
member.param: Pass in a reference to the exception being reported, from which private method AddCommonElements, which may get folded into it, extracts the TargetSite, StackTrace, and other common properties, depending on the current state of the option flags.

Pass in a reference to the partially constructed message, which has the raw or parsed message, along with other properties that vary by exception type.
This StringBuilder is eventually sent to the console if the option flags so indicate, and becomes the value returned by the method.

Pass in a reference to the partially constructed message, which has the raw or parsed message, along with other properties that vary by exception type.
This StringBuilder is eventually sent to a Windows Event Log, if the option flags so indicate; otherwise, it is discarded.
member.returns: The completed sbLogMsg is always returned to the calling routine, which may dispose of it as it sees fit, and usually discards it if the calling routine is a console program, or displays it in a message box if the program is running in the graphical subsystem.

member.name: M:WizardWrx.DLLConfigurationManager.ExceptionLogger.PrepareMessageForEventLog(System.Text.StringBuilder)
member.summary: Prepare the log message for the event log by replacing newlines with a non-breaking space followed by a newline, a non-breaking space, by itself, or nothing, depending on the values of the DiscardNewlines and NBSpaceForNewlines bits on the _enmOutputOptions bit mask.
member.param: The input is the string constructed from the components of the exception, which usually contains numerous newlines, since the event log always gets a complete report.
member.returns: The returned string has newlines either preserved or replaced, ready to go into the event log.

member.name: M:WizardWrx.DLLConfigurationManager.ExceptionLogger.AddCommonElements(System.Text.StringBuilder,System.Text.StringBuilder,System.Exception,WizardWrx.DLLConfigurationManager.ExceptionLogger.OutputOptions)
member.summary: Add the Source, TargetSite, and StackTrace properties to the exception report. See Remarks.
member.param: Append the report items to this StringBuilder.

Since the stack trace is always included, the message for the event log must be assembled separately. If event logging is disabled, this argument is a null reference, so we don't waste effort if it would be discarded.
This is an instance of the System.Exception class, or one of its derivatives. See Remarks.
Combine members of the OutputOptions enumeration to specify items to include in the report, and how to log the error. (The enumeration is a bit mask.)
member.remarks:
This method is called recursively to process inner exceptions.
By default, all exceptions which derive from System.Exception expose these three properties, and any of them can be cast to this type.
The TargetSite string contains the name of the method that threw the exception.
The Source string contains the name of the class to which the method named in the TargetSite string belongs.

member.name: M:WizardWrx.DLLConfigurationManager.ExceptionLogger.CreateForEventLog(WizardWrx.DLLConfigurationManager.ExceptionLogger.OutputOptions)
member.summary: Return a new empty StringBuilder if event logging is enabled. Otherwise, return a null reference, which signals the exception reporting routines to skip building a message for it.
member.param: Since some of the methods with which it works are static because they are called recursively, this routine must also be static, and it must receive a copy of the OutputOptions bit mask.
member.returns: If a copy of the report is bound for a Windows event log, it is constructed in the StringBuilder returned by this method. Otherwise, the null reference signals the message formatters not to bother.

member.name: M:WizardWrx.DLLConfigurationManager.ExceptionLogger.FormatStackTrace(System.Exception)
member.summary: Format the stack trace to make it (hopefully) a tad easier to read.
member.param: A reference to the entire exception is passed into the method, from which this routine extracts the stack trace.
member.returns: The returned string contains the formatted stack trace.

member.name: M:WizardWrx.DLLConfigurationManager.ExceptionLogger.GetDefaultEventSourceID
member.summary: Read the default event source ID string from the DLL configuration.
member.returns:
If the function succeeds, the return value is the event source ID string stored in the configuration file that comes along for the ride whenever this DLL is imported into a project. Otherwise, the default event source ID defined in WIZARDWRX_EVENT_SOURCE_ID is returned.
To save trips to the disk or its cache, once read, the event source ID is cached in static string s_strDefaultEventSource.

member.name: M:WizardWrx.DLLConfigurationManager.ExceptionLogger.GetMessageTruncationStart(System.Guid)
member.summary: Look up the exception in the list of known exceptions and, if found, return a string that marks the point where the displayed message is to be truncated.
member.param: This string contains the fully qualified type name of the exception, which is the key to an public Dictionary of strings that mark the point where the message should be truncated for display. Please see the Remarks section.
member.returns: The return value, which may be the empty string, is text, such as a fixed label, that marks a point where the message supplied by the exception is truncated.
member.remarks:
Typically, a message is truncated because we present the information in a more visually appealing and/or accessible format. Of the myriad exceptions exposed by the Base Class Library, not to mention custom exceptions derived from System.Exception, only a handful are "known" types that require attention.
Messages from types that are unknown to this class (i. e., they have no entry in the s_dctKnowExceptionTypes dictionary, are preserved.
This private method hides the processing required to cover for the unknown exception type.

member.name: M:WizardWrx.DLLConfigurationManager.ExceptionLogger.ReformatExceptionMessage(System.Exception,System.String,System.String)
member.summary: This private method beautifies the format of invalid argument exception reports.
member.param: Reference to exception from which to extract and format its Message property.
This string identifies the place in the source code where the exception was thrown.
Format string, suitable for use with String.Format, from which the beautified message is constructed.
member.returns: Beautified string, suitable for presentation on a console.

member.name: M:WizardWrx.DLLConfigurationManager.ExceptionLogger.SetDefaultOptions
member.summary: The purpose of this routine is to keep the code that sets the default option flags in one place only.
member.returns: The return value is the OutputOptions bit mask with all flags set to their initial default values.
member.remarks: I expect this one-line syntactic candy to be optimized away in the Release build.

member.name: M:WizardWrx.DLLConfigurationManager.ExceptionLogger.InitializeInstance(WizardWrx.DLLConfigurationManager.ExceptionLogger,WizardWrx.AssemblyUtils.PESubsystemInfo.PESubsystemID)
member.summary: Synchronize old and new flags and set default message colors if necessary.
member.param: Since this method must be static, a reference to the ExceptionLogger singleton must be passed into it.
Use this member of the ProcessSubsystem enumeration to modify the default behavior of the exception logging methods, by enabling console output if the calling application has one.

member.name: M:WizardWrx.DLLConfigurationManager.ExceptionLogger.UseEventLog(WizardWrx.DLLConfigurationManager.ExceptionLogger.OutputOptions)
member.summary: Hide the complexity of bit mask testing from cursory scanning of the code, so that the reader doesn't feel compelled to slow down to study the bit test. At compile time, this routine is optimized away, replaced by inline code.
member.param: The OutputOptions enumeration is organized for use as a bit mask. Set its flags as desired to control the format and content of output generated by the ReportException methods.
member.returns: Return TRUE if event logging is enabled.

member.name: T:WizardWrx.DLLConfigurationManager.IniFileReader
member.summary: Provide a managed interface to GetPrivateProfileString in the Windows API, with methods to retrieve the values of individual keys and lists of the keys in a section or the sections in a file.

member.name: F:WizardWrx.DLLConfigurationManager.IniFileReader.path
member.summary: This string holds the fully qualified name of the private profile file to process, which is passed into the constructor, but can be changed as needed.

member.name: M:WizardWrx.DLLConfigurationManager.IniFileReader.#ctor(System.String)
member.summary: Construct an instance of the class.
member.param: This string must be the fully qualified name of a well formed private profile (INI) file.

member.name: M:WizardWrx.DLLConfigurationManager.IniFileReader.GetSectionNames
member.summary: The Function called to obtain the SectionHeaders, and returns them in an Dynamic Array
member.returns: The return value is an array of strings, each of which is the name of a section.

member.name: M:WizardWrx.DLLConfigurationManager.IniFileReader.GetEntryNames(System.String)
member.summary: The Function called to obtain the EntryKeys from the given SectionHeader string passed, and returns them in an Dynamic Array
member.param: This string must be the name of a section which is expected to be present, though possibly empty.
member.returns: The return value is an array of strings, each of which is the name of a key (entry) in the specified section.

member.name: M:WizardWrx.DLLConfigurationManager.IniFileReader.GetEntryValue(System.String,System.String)
member.summary: The Function called to obtain the EntryKey Value from the given SectionHeader and EntryKey string passed, then returned
member.param: This string must be the name of a section that is expected to exist.
This string must be the name of a key (entry) that is expected to exist, though it might be empty.
member.returns: The return value is a string, which may be empty.

member.name: T:WizardWrx.DLLConfigurationManager.StateManager
member.summary: This class maintains run-time information about the executing assembly, assumed to be a desktop application, that calls it into being. Since it implements the Singleton design pattern, there is never more than one instance.
member.remarks: This class has several read-write properties, all of which are protected by thread-safe accessors. Both the Get and Set methods are protected, so that a get request blocks until a set request executing in another thread completes.

member.name: F:WizardWrx.DLLConfigurationManager.StateManager.ASSEMBLYVERSION_COMPLETE
member.summary: Specify this constant to the ToString method of a System.Version object (e. g., of an Assembly) to cause it to return the entire version string.

member.name: F:WizardWrx.DLLConfigurationManager.StateManager.ASSEMBLYVERSION_EXCEPT_REVISION
member.summary: Specify this constant to the ToString method of a System.Version object (e. g., of an Assembly) to cause it to return all but the build number.

member.name: F:WizardWrx.DLLConfigurationManager.StateManager.ASSEMBLYVERSION_MAJOR_AND_MINOR
member.summary: Specify this constant to the ToString method of a System.Version object (e. g., of an Assembly) to cause it to return only the major and minor version numbers.

member.name: F:WizardWrx.DLLConfigurationManager.StateManager.ASSEMBLYVERSION_MAJOR_ONLY
member.summary: Specify this constant to the ToString method of a System.Version object (e. g., of an Assembly) to cause it to return only the major version number.

member.name: T:WizardWrx.DLLConfigurationManager.StateManager.AssemblyVersionRequest
member.summary: Use this enumeration as input to the overloaded StateManager class's GetAssemblyProductAndVersion method, to specify how many parts of the version string to return.

member.name: F:WizardWrx.DLLConfigurationManager.StateManager.AssemblyVersionRequest.MajorOnly
member.summary: This is functionally equivalent to specifying a constant value of ASSEMBLYVERSION_MAJOR_ONLY to the ToString method of a System.Version object, and is intended to do so through the GetAssemblyProductAndVersion instance method of this class.

member.name: F:WizardWrx.DLLConfigurationManager.StateManager.AssemblyVersionRequest.MajorAndMinor
member.summary: This is functionally equivalent to specifying a constant value of ASSEMBLYVERSION_MAJOR_AND_MINOR to the ToString method of a System.Version object, and is intended to do so through the GetAssemblyProductAndVersion instance method of this class.

member.name: F:WizardWrx.DLLConfigurationManager.StateManager.AssemblyVersionRequest.MajroMinorBuild
member.summary:
This is functionally equivalent to specifying a constant value of ASSEMBLYVERSION_EXCEPT_REVISION to the ToString method of a System.Version object, and is intended to do so through the GetAssemblyProductAndVersion instance method of this class.
MajroMinorBuild and MajorMinorExceptRevision are synonyms.

member.name: F:WizardWrx.DLLConfigurationManager.StateManager.AssemblyVersionRequest.MajorMinorExceptRevision
member.summary:
This is functionally equivalent to specifying a constant value of ASSEMBLYVERSION_EXCEPT_REVISION to the ToString method of a System.Version object, and is intended to do so through the GetAssemblyProductAndVersion instance method of this class.
MajroMinorBuild and MajorMinorExceptRevision are synonyms.

member.name: F:WizardWrx.DLLConfigurationManager.StateManager.AssemblyVersionRequest.MajorMinroBuildRevision
member.summary:
This is functionally equivalent to specifying a constant value of ASSEMBLYVERSION_COMPLETE to the ToString method of a System.Version object, and is intended to do so through the GetAssemblyProductAndVersion instance method of this class.
MajorMinroBuildRevision and Complete are synonyms.

member.name: F:WizardWrx.DLLConfigurationManager.StateManager.AssemblyVersionRequest.Complete
member.summary:
This is functionally equivalent to specifying a constant value of ASSEMBLYVERSION_COMPLETE to the ToString method of a System.Version object, and is intended to do so through the GetAssemblyProductAndVersion instance method of this class.
MajorMinroBuildRevision and Complete are synonyms.

member.name: F:WizardWrx.DLLConfigurationManager.StateManager.UNSUPPORTED_EXE_SUBSYSTEM
member.summary: The DWLastDllError property returns this value when StandardHandleState is called by code running in anything except the Windows character mode subsystem.

member.name: M:WizardWrx.DLLConfigurationManager.StateManager.#ctor
member.summary: To prevent the framework from generating a default constructor and marking it public, which would break the singleton design pattern, we provide our own do-nothing constructor.

member.name: M:WizardWrx.DLLConfigurationManager.StateManager.GetTheSingleInstance(System.Reflection.Assembly)
member.summary: Call this method from any class that exposes a reference to the singleton as a read only property. Please see the Remarks section.
member.param: Pass in a reference to the assembly that is calling this method on behalf of an object that exposes a reference to this object as a read only property. Please see the Remarks section.
member.returns: The return value is a reference to the singleton, which is created the first time the method is called. Subsequent calls return a reference to the singleton.
member.remarks:
Since making a protected constructor safe for use by a class that implements the Singleton design pattern, and a class that calls this method causes System.Reflection.Assembly.GetCalllingAssembly to report the assembly in which the call executes as the calling assembly, any such method must explicitly identify the assembly that contains the process entry point.
When the Visual Studio Hosting Process is enabled, it becomes the entry assembly, hiding the "real" entry assembly (the assembly under test), System.Reflection.Assembly.GetEntryAssembly cannot be used safely. Moreover, since the Visual Studio Hosting Process runs in the graphical (Windows) subsystem, the entry assembly cannot be used to correctly determine whether the entry assembly runs in the character mode subsystem.
Although the class needs only the Location property off the Assembly instance, I elected to call for the entire Assembly to be passed in, to make the needs of this method unambiguous. Since the calling method must call one of two static methods on the Assembly class, both of which return instances of Assembly, this doesn't impose any extra burden on the calling assembly.

member.name: M:WizardWrx.DLLConfigurationManager.StateManager.GetAssemblyFQFN
member.summary: Return the fully qualified name of the assembly that started the current process.
member.returns: The return value is a string that contains the fully qualified name of the assembly that started the current process.
member.remarks: I made this a method so that it is computed as needed, even in a debugging session when the Visual Studio Hosting process runs all the property getters when an object is expanded in the locals and watch windows.

member.name: M:WizardWrx.DLLConfigurationManager.StateManager.GetAssemblyProductAndVersion
member.summary: Get the assembly product name and version number is a string that is suitable for use as a window caption.
member.returns: The return value is a string, suitable for use as the caption of a window, such as a form or message box. The returned string contains the product name, followed by the entire 4-part version string.

member.name: M:WizardWrx.DLLConfigurationManager.StateManager.GetAssemblyProductAndVersion(WizardWrx.DLLConfigurationManager.StateManager.AssemblyVersionRequest)
member.summary: Get the assembly product name and version number is a string that is suitable for use as a window caption.
member.param: Use a member of the AssemblyVersionRequest enumeration to indicate how many parts of the four-part version number to include.
member.returns: The return value is a string, suitable for use as the caption of a window, such as a form or message box. The returned string contains the product name, followed by the specified number of parts of the product version.

member.name: M:WizardWrx.DLLConfigurationManager.StateManager.GetAppSubsystemID
member.summary: Return the AppSubsystemID property, explicitly cast to a PESubsystemID.
member.returns: The return value is the AppSubsystemID property, cast to a member of the ESubsystemInfo.PESubsystemID enumeration.
member.remarks:
This method provides a more meaningful interpretation of the AppSubsystemID value.
This routine is implemented as an instance method, so that its code runs only as needed.

member.name: M:WizardWrx.DLLConfigurationManager.StateManager.GetAppSubsystemString
member.summary: Return a sentence that identifies the subsystem in which the assembly that started the current process runs.
member.returns: The return value is a short sentence that describes the subsystem in which the assembly that started the current process runs.
member.remarks:
I made this a method so that it is computed strictly as needed, even in a debugging session when the Visual Studio Hosting process runs all the property getters when an object is expanded in the locals or watch window.
This method is much more expensive than GetAssemblyFQFN, because it gets the returned string from a string resource.

member.name: M:WizardWrx.DLLConfigurationManager.StateManager.LoadErrorMessageTable(System.String[])
member.summary: Load the table of error messages for use with the ErrorExit method.
member.param: Array of strings, for use as error messages. See Remarks.
member.returns: Count of error messages loaded into the object. Hence, the Ubound of the array is one less than the return value, and its LBound is zero.
member.remarks:
Error message numbers are array subscripts. This imposes two requirements on the list.
1) You must supply a message for the default exit code of zero, even if you don't use it.
2) Status codes must be sequentially numbered.
The second requirement can be relaxed, at the cost of inserting one or more dummy error messages, which may be empty strings, to account for the skipped numbers. The obvious disadvantage is some bloat in the message table.
You must call this method before your program can get a useful error message from ErrorExit. Although the call to ErrorExit succeeds, the message is "Internal error: Unknown status code," followed by the supplied raw exit code.

member.name: P:WizardWrx.DLLConfigurationManager.StateManager.AppErrorMessages
member.summary: Make the array of error messages available, for reading only, under guard of a lock, to ensure that another thread isn't adding to the array while it is being returned.

member.name: P:WizardWrx.DLLConfigurationManager.StateManager.AppReturnCode
member.summary: Use this read/write property to set the application return code from anywhere, so that you don't have to use another, potentially awkward, method to get the word back to the main routine.
member.remarks: Access to this property is synchronized by an internally managed object lock.

member.name: P:WizardWrx.DLLConfigurationManager.StateManager.AppRootAssemblyFileBaseName
member.summary: This property is a shortcut to the AssemblyFileBaseName property of the AppRootAssembly property.
member.remarks: Since the underlying property is read only, and has a static initializer, it is thread-safe without the overhead of a lock.

member.name: P:WizardWrx.DLLConfigurationManager.StateManager.AppRootAssemblyFileDirName
member.summary: This property is a shortcut to the AssembyDirName property of the AppRootAssembly property.
member.remarks: Since the underlying property is read only, and has a static initializer, it is thread-safe without the overhead of a lock.

member.name: P:WizardWrx.DLLConfigurationManager.StateManager.AppRootAssemblyFileName
member.summary: This property is a shortcut to the AssemblyFileName property of the AppRootAssembly property.
member.remarks: Since the underlying property is read only, and has a static initializer, it is thread-safe without the overhead of a lock.

member.name: P:WizardWrx.DLLConfigurationManager.StateManager.AppRootAssemblyName
member.summary: This property returns the fully qualified name of the root assembly, the first assembly that loaded into the default application domain.
member.remarks: This property yields a wealth of information about the assembly, including all four parts of its version number, its public key token, if it has one, and its culture.

member.name: P:WizardWrx.DLLConfigurationManager.StateManager.AppStartupTimeLocal
member.summary: This property is a shortcut to the StartupTime property of the AppRootAssembly property.
member.remarks: Since the underlying property is read only, and has a static initializer, it is thread-safe without the overhead of a lock.

member.name: P:WizardWrx.DLLConfigurationManager.StateManager.AppStartupTimeUtc
member.summary: This property is a shortcut to the StartupTimeUTC property of the AppRootAssembly property.
member.remarks: Since the underlying property is read only, and has a static initializer, it is thread-safe without the overhead of a lock.

member.name: P:WizardWrx.DLLConfigurationManager.StateManager.AppUptime
member.summary: Gets the elapsed time since the application started.

member.name: P:WizardWrx.DLLConfigurationManager.StateManager.AppSubsystemID
member.summary: Return the ID of the subsystem in which the assembly runs. Call the GetAppSubsystemString method to translate the ID into a human readable message. The translation is way too expensive to expose as a property, and too infrequently needed to justify having the constructor store it in a string.

member.name: P:WizardWrx.DLLConfigurationManager.StateManager.ConsoleMessageTimeFormat
member.summary: Use this property to get a reference to the FormattedLocalTime object that governs the formatting of the times displayed in the BOJ and EOJ messages.

member.name: P:WizardWrx.DLLConfigurationManager.StateManager.DefaultEventSourceID
member.summary: Gets the registered default event source ID.
member.remarks: If no event source is registered, this property returns the WIZARDWRX_EVENT_SOURCE_ID string static ExceptionLogger string.

member.name: P:WizardWrx.DLLConfigurationManager.StateManager.InitialWorkingDirectoryName
member.summary: Gets the initial working directory, which reflects its value when the application started.
member.remarks: This property has a static initializer, and is never changed.

member.name: P:WizardWrx.DLLConfigurationManager.StateManager.DWLastDllError
member.summary: Query this property for the value returned by GetLastError.
member.remarks: Strictly speaking, the value is returned by Marshal.GetLastWin32Error.

member.name: P:WizardWrx.DLLConfigurationManager.StateManager.AppExceptionLogger
member.summary: This property returns a reference to the singleton ExceptionLogger, which is created immediately following creation of this instance. Hence, by the time the reference is returned, this reference is guaranteed to be valid and read only for work.

member.name: P:WizardWrx.DLLConfigurationManager.StateManager.ShowUTCTime
member.summary:
Set this property to TRUE to cause UTC times to be displayed in all time stamps included in console BOJ and EOJ messages.
Set it to FALSE to display only local times. The class default setting is TRUE.
See the Remarks listed with the class definition.

member.name: M:WizardWrx.DLLConfigurationManager.StateManager.GetStdHandleFQFN(WizardWrx.ConsoleStreams.StandardHandleInfo.StandardConsoleHandle)
member.summary: Report the file, if any, to which the specified standard handle is redirected.
member.param: Specify the StandardHandleInfo.StandardConsoleHandle member that corresponds to the handle for which you wish to know whether it is attached or redirected.
member.returns:
If the function succeeds and the handle is redirected, the return value is the name of the file to which the specified handle is redirected.
Otherwise, the return value is one of two strings that explain the error.
Properties.Resources.MSG_APP_CHARACTER_MODE_APPS_ONLY is the complete text of the message displayed when the calling routine is running in the Windows graphical mode subsystem.
Properties.Resources.ERRMSG_STD_HANDLE_STATE is the beginning of a message, which is followed by the returned system status code, shown in both hexadecimal and decimal notation, followed by the associated system message.

member.name: M:WizardWrx.DLLConfigurationManager.StateManager.StandardHandleState(WizardWrx.ConsoleStreams.StandardHandleInfo.StandardConsoleHandle)
member.summary: Evaluate whether a standard handle is attached to a console or redirected.
member.param: Specify the StandardHandleInfo.StandardConsoleHandle member that corresponds to the handle for which you wish to know whether it is attached or redirected.
member.returns: If the function succeeds, the return value is either ShsAttached or ShsRedirected. Otherwise, there was an error, and you should call Marshal.GetLastWin32Error to determine exactly what happened. The singleton has a private property where the return value is stored.

member.name: M:WizardWrx.DLLConfigurationManager.StateManager.FormatSystemErrorMessage(System.Int32)
member.summary: Return the message associated with a system status code.
member.param: Specify the status code for which the system message is desired.
member.returns: A new Win32Exception exception is constructed from the specified status code, and its Message property is returned.
member.remarks: This convenience method amounts to syntactic sugar. Since it is very unlikely to ever be called by the method that motivated me to create it, I'll let it go ahead and call through it, even though calling the constructor directly, passing in the static member that holds the status code would be a couple of orders of magnitude more efficient.

member.name: T:WizardWrx.DLLConfigurationManager.Properties.Resources
member.summary: A strongly-typed resource class, for looking up localized strings, etc.

member.name: P:WizardWrx.DLLConfigurationManager.Properties.Resources.ResourceManager
member.summary: Returns the cached ResourceManager instance used by this class.

member.name: P:WizardWrx.DLLConfigurationManager.Properties.Resources.Culture
member.summary: Overrides the current thread's CurrentUICulture property for all resource lookups using this strongly typed resource class.

member.name: P:WizardWrx.DLLConfigurationManager.Properties.Resources.DEFAULT_EVENT_SOURCE_ID
member.summary: Looks up a localized string similar to DefaultWindowsEventSourceID.

member.name: P:WizardWrx.DLLConfigurationManager.Properties.Resources.ERRMSG_ARGNAME_TPL

member.name: P:WizardWrx.DLLConfigurationManager.Properties.Resources.ERRMSG_ARGVALUE_TPL

member.name: P:WizardWrx.DLLConfigurationManager.Properties.Resources.ERRMSG_ASM_SUBSYSTEM

member.name: P:WizardWrx.DLLConfigurationManager.Properties.Resources.ERRMSG_EX_MSG_TPL
member.summary: Looks up a localized string similar to An {0} exception was caught in routine {1}:{3} Message = {2}{3}.

member.name: P:WizardWrx.DLLConfigurationManager.Properties.Resources.ERRMSG_FILENAME_TPL
member.summary: Looks up a localized string similar to File Name = {0}{1}.

member.name: P:WizardWrx.DLLConfigurationManager.Properties.Resources.ERRMSG_FORMATSTRING_TPL
